comment_text: StarWolf watched this.

I doubt I'll get an answer for this, but if they used front surface mirrors, why does the footage have a blurry distortion to it? It looks to me like they used back surface mirrors, or if double sides mirrors, used the wrong side. There were a couple of clips that really stood out in Mark's video due their sharpness, as well as it didn't seem as though the spinning mirror effect was being used at all. Like, they were done with the camera on a tripod aimed at the subject like normal. If they were part of the spinning apparatus, why did they look different?

0:05
AYYY 2013 Mark Rober

Question: Since I see no drop cloths or polyethylene  (with bullets going through glass would require 100 feet out and maybe 20 feet or more on the sides, and less on the back) in any of your videos, how do you clean up all the glass so no one else is ever cut by it?
Thanks yt recomended 8 years to late!

I wonder if it’s possible to get the bullet time effect with no moving parts or multiple cameras. Basically instead of surrounding the subject with cameras, or using a spinning mirror. What if we had a reflective surface that surrounded the subject. Instinctively I’m thinking a mirrored surface donut, but maybe there are more optimal shapes. If you put the subject in the middle of the shiny donut, and put the camera below, I reckon the camera can see the subject from all sides. Of course it will be very distorted, but each frame has enough data in it to have a 360 image. In post processing you can undistort the image to simulate a spinning camera.

One thing I am not able to get my head around:
Why did you have to motion-track/correct the video?
The mirrors are going to be stable from the camera's perspective, no?

I am a Senior Radar Technician in the Canadian Navy and I have gone through your entire catalogue of videos a few times.  I had an issue where a Azimuth motor and Bearing set was wearing out faster than it should have and thanks in part to this video I figured out that it was spinning an unbalanced rotational load and that caused vibration and sheer force, wearing out the components faster.  Thanks for being an entertaining educator and not being afraid to post the videos and plans that didn't work as intended.

this is an engineering design fail. try using a circle of mirrors around what you are filming. then add a spinning mirror above it. then place the camera on top. this will also remove the support bars from the picture. you will also be ale to change the angle of the picture by adjusting the circle of mirrors. just trying to help.

The company that produces this particular t-slot extrusion is called 80/20 inc. and you can see their products just do a web search on that name.  This extrusion is wonderful to work with and when you are done with one project you can break it down and use for some other project.  There are many retailers that sell including McMaster-Carr.

If you don't agree with the faith, you can appreciate the overall applicability of the passage he shared:  testing produces perseverance.  It's a parallel observation of his experience of failure to the one in the video.  This may not be the place to argue about who wrote it, when, or why, but to notice that the person who wrote it made a similar observation of the same principle in a different context a long time ago.
